artist: Utagawa Hiroshige; Published by Nishimuraya Yohachi
creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
marks: Asagao no/ hanada no iro no/ hatsu-gatsuo/ ni no k Ichiryūsai Hiroshige ga 一立斎広重画
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
text: The combination of a bonito with twigs of cherry suggests early summer, when cherry trees begin to fruit and the season’s first bonitos are caught. Both of the poems on this print refer to hatsu-gatsuo (first bonito), the first catch of the season. Traditionally, the Japanese place a high value on hatsu-mono (first foods), the earliest fruits, vegetables, or fish of a particular season. The “first bonito” was the most prized of all and commanded a high price. People anticipated this seasonal delicacy with much excitement, as described in the poems. Look at the color of the first bonitos! They are as blue as morning glories. No wonder they come along to market before the sun rises. Toshinokado Haruki The first bonito caught on the beach near the place called Under Snow melts like snow in my mouth. How tasty it is! Toshiiori Machikado
title: Bonito and Saxifrage
